title: How to Mill Wheat

steps.headline: Buy a grain mill if you process wheat for baking on a regular basis.
steps.description:
Grain mills can be a little pricey, ranging from $100 to about $550, depending on what brand you purchase, but they can be well worth the investment if you find yourself often needing to mill wheat for your baking needs. Here are some things to consider before you make your purchase:
Hopper capacity
Price
Settings for fine versus coarse grinds
How much space it’ll take up on your counter
Return policies and warranties

steps.headline: Use a manual wheat grinder for an electricity-free, hands-on product.
steps.description: Some bakers believe a manual (hand-crank) mill produces better-tasting bread. Others like it because it lets them use their hands throughout the entire milling process and makes them feel even more connected to their food. They’re also less expensive than electric mills, running from about $25 to $60 depending on the brand. Most hand-operated mills get clamped onto the edge of a table or counter. They come with a crank that you work to move the wheat berries through the grinder.Tip: It generally takes about 2 minutes of cranking to mill 1 cup (125 grams) of flour, so keep that in mind when making your decision about electric versus manual mills.

steps.headline: Pick the right type of wheat for your baking needs.
steps.description:
Wheat is categorized by its color, shape, and by whether or not it’s “hard” or “soft.” Each kind has a different protein content (the higher the protein level, the more elastic the dough will be), which is how you can decide what typed of baked good it’ll be the before for. Here are the 6 different types of wheat and what they’re most often used for:
Hard red winter wheat: breads and rolls, has a high percentage of protein. Hard red spring wheat: breads and rolls; has a high percentage of protein. Soft red winter wheat: brown crackers, flatbreads, and “whole grain” items. Durum wheat: pasta and breads; has a higher percentage of protein content. Hard white wheat: cakes, cookies, pastries, and muffins; has a very low percentage of protein. Soft white wheat: cakes, cookies, pastries, and muffins; has a very low percentage of protein.

steps.headline: Mill 1 cup (250 grams) of wheat berries for 2 cups (350 grams) of flour.
steps.description: Wheat berries (or kernels) are harvested from wheat stalks and resemble little grains of brown rice. They're very dense, so when they get ground up, they make more bulk than when they were unground. Wheat berries can also be used whole. Simply boil them and add them to salads or hot cereals for a healthy, nutrient-dense addition to your dish.Tip: For the freshest tasting baked goods, mill your wheat as close to baking as possible. You can definitely mill it ahead of time, though. In general, milled wheat is freshest within the first 3 days. After that, keep it in the fridge in an airtight container for up to 7 days or freeze it for up to 6 months.

steps.headline: Set a glass bowl beneath the grinder’s spout to catch the milled wheat.
steps.description: Use a clean, non-porous container to catch your flour. Position it so it’s centered underneath the spout (or nozzle) of your grinder. If you’re worried about it slipping, set it on top of a rubber mat or a dishtowel. Stainless steel would also work well if you don’t have a glass bowl available. Plus, depending on what you’re making, you could just use that same bowl to start preparing your recipe.

steps.headline: Adjust the setting for the coarseness of the grind for your baking needs.
steps.description: Most of the time, you will want to use the finest grind possible. A coarser grind would be good for hot cereal, pancakes, cracked wheat, or other similar products. Always check the mill’s instructions for tips and methods on how to best use it.

steps.headline: Turn on your grinder and pour the wheat berries into the hopper.
steps.description: Make sure the grinder is plugged in. You can turn it on either before or after you’ve added the wheat berries. Simply let the machine run until all the wheat berries have been processed. If you’re using a manual grinder, pour the wheat berries into the hopper, adjust the grinding setting, and start turning that crank!

steps.headline: Let the flour settle before measuring for a recipe.
steps.description: Most recipes call for amounts of flour that have settled and that haven’t just had lots of air whipped through it during the milling process. Either plan to mill your flour about 30 minutes before you’ll need to use it, or plan on lightly packing it into a measuring cup so you can get the right amount. To lightly pack the flour into a measuring cup, scoop the flour into the cup and use the back of a spoon to gently press the flour down so it compresses a little bit, kind of like how you would measure packed brown sugar.

methods.name: Grinding Wheat without a Grain Mill

steps.headline: Run the wheat berries through a coffee grinder twice to mill it.
steps.description: Before using your coffee grinder, take some time to thoroughly clean it out with water and a gentle soap to remove any lingering coffee grounds and oils from the beans. After you’ve ground the berries, sift the flour to remove any larger chunks that remain. After you’ve sifted the flour, you can re-grind the remaining bits or simply discard them.

steps.headline: Use a food processor and run the flour through a sieve afterward.
steps.description: Make sure the food processor is clean before you use it. Run the wheat berries through the processor for about 30 seconds or until they appear to be finely ground. Sift through the flour and re-grind any larger chunks that still exist. It’s really important to make sure the food processor is clean and dry before you use it on your wheat berries, just to prevent any kind of cross-contamination that might spoil your flour.

steps.headline: Put wheat berries through a high-powered blender.
steps.description: Clean and dry the blender before you use it. Since there is more room for the flour to move around in, you’ll want to sift through the wheat berries often to continually remove the ground flour and continue processing the berries that remain. Keep in mind that your blender isn’t meant to grind hard things, like the wheat berries, so it may cause the blades to wear down a bit faster than they would with normal use.

steps.headline: Purchase an attachment for a KitchenAid mixer to mill your wheat.
steps.description: This is a great option if you happen to have a KitchenAid. It’s a fairly silent process, unlike many other methods for milling wheat which tend to get pretty noisy. Plus, you can use the attachment to grind other foods, like oats, flax, chia seeds, and the like.Warning: The attachment costs about $160 and is only made for certain models of the KitchenAid, so make sure you check the specifications before you make a purchase.

steps.headline: Keep unmilled wheat berries in a sealed container in a dry, cool location.
steps.description: They’ll last for up to 6 months in a pantry or for up to 12 months if you pop them into the freezer. Mark down the “purchased date” so you can keep track of how long they’ll be good for. If the wheat berries have a musty or oily smell, they’re no longer good. Wheat berries that are still viable usually have no scent, or they might smell just a little sweet.

steps.headline: Use milled wheat within 3 days of grinding it or store it safely.
steps.description: When you mill wheat at home, all the oils and proteins and fats from the wheat berries are left in your flour, which means it’ll start to go bad way before the kind of flour you purchase from the store would. For the first couple of days, you can keep it in an airtight container on the counter, but after 3 days, it’ll need to be moved to the fridge or freezer. If your home is particularly warm, you may want to plan to use the milled wheat within 24 hours, just to be safe, or move it to the fridge.

steps.headline: Refrigerate milled wheat for up to 7 days or freeze it for up to 6 months.
steps.description: After the initial 3 days after milling have passed, it’s time to transfer the unused flour to a better storage location. Keep it in an airtight container and place it either into the fridge or the freezer, just depending on how soon you think you might want to use it.Tip: Write the “milled date” on the container so you can track how long it has been in storage for.

steps.headline: Discard milled wheat when it develops a rancid smell.
steps.description: If you open a container of flour and notice that it smells a little funky, you’re better off throwing it out and grinding a fresh batch for your baking needs. You could also add it to a compost pile if you have one. Spoiled flour can make you sick, and at the very least, it’ll make anything you bake taste off.
